canonical_explanation.text: The p-block elements span Groups 13 to 18 of the periodic table. In CBSE Class 12, the focus is on Groups 15 (nitrogen family), 16 (oxygen family), 17 (halogens), and 18 (noble gases). Group 15 elements (N, P, As, Sb, Bi) have the general electronic configuration ns²np³. Nitrogen is unique due to its small size, high electronegativity, and ability to form pπ–pπ multiple bonds. NH₃ is a Lewis base and a ligand. Nitrogen forms oxides from N₂O to N₂O₅ with varying oxidation states (+1 to +5). Phosphorus exhibits allotropy (white, red, black phosphorus) and forms oxoacids such as H₃PO₃ (dibasic) and H₃PO₄ (tribasic). Group 16 elements (O, S, Se, Te, Po) have ns²np⁴ configuration. Oxygen exhibits allotropy (O₂ and O₃). Sulphur shows catenation and forms numerous allotropes; the most stable is rhombic sulphur (S₈). H₂SO₄ is manufactured by the Contact process and is a strong dibasic acid, powerful dehydrating agent, and oxidising agent. SO₂ and SO₃ are important oxides. Group 17 elements (F, Cl, Br, I, At) are the halogens with ns²np⁵ configuration. They are highly electronegative and form strong oxidising agents. Fluorine is the most electronegative element and most powerful oxidising halogen. HF exhibits hydrogen bonding, leading to a high boiling point. Interhalogen compounds (ClF₃, BrF₅, IF₇) are more reactive than halogens. Oxoacids of chlorine include HClO, HClO₂, HClO₃, and HClO₄, with increasing acid strength and decreasing oxidising power. Group 18 elements (He, Ne, Ar, Kr, Xe, Rn) are noble gases with completely filled ns²np⁶ configuration (except He: 1s²). Xenon forms compounds with fluorine (XeF₂, XeF₄, XeF₆) and oxygen (XeO₃, XeOF₂), demonstrating that noble gases are not completely inert. The structures of xenon fluorides are predicted by VSEPR theory.
rules: Group 15 elements have ns²np³ configuration; nitrogen shows a maximum covalency of 4 (no d orbitals), while P, As, Sb can expand their octet.
NH₃ is pyramidal (sp³ with one lone pair); it acts as a Lewis base and forms complexes with transition metals.
Phosphorus acid (H₃PO₃) is dibasic despite having three H atoms because only two OH groups are present; the third H is directly bonded to P.
Group 16 elements have ns²np⁴ configuration; oxygen is the second most electronegative element after fluorine.
H₂SO₄ is manufactured by the Contact process: 2SO₂ + O₂ → 2SO₃ (catalyst: V₂O₅), followed by absorption in H₂SO₄ to form oleum.
Ozone (O₃) is a powerful oxidising agent and has an angular structure with a bond angle of ~117°.
Group 17 elements have ns²np⁵; they have the highest electron affinity among all elements (Cl has the highest EA, not F, due to small size and electron repulsion in F).
Fluorine is the strongest oxidising halogen because of its low bond dissociation energy, high hydration enthalpy of F⁻, and high electronegativity.
Interhalogen compounds have the general formula XYn (n = 1, 3, 5, 7); the larger halogen is the central atom.
Among oxoacids of chlorine, acid strength increases as HClO < HClO₂ < HClO₃ < HClO₄ due to increasing number of oxygen atoms stabilising the conjugate base.
Group 18 elements have fully filled orbitals; Xe forms fluorides (XeF₂ linear, XeF₄ square planar, XeF₆ distorted octahedral) due to availability of empty 5d orbitals.
XeF₂ has 3 lone pairs on Xe (linear, sp³d), XeF₄ has 2 lone pairs (square planar, sp³d²), XeF₆ has 1 lone pair (distorted octahedral, sp³d³).

questions.question_text: The general electronic configuration of Group 15 elements is:
questions.explanation_correct: Group 15 elements (N, P, As, Sb, Bi) have five electrons in their outermost shell with the configuration ns²np³, giving them three half-filled p orbitals.
questions.explanation_incorrect: ns²np² is Group 14, ns²np⁴ is Group 16, and ns²np⁵ is Group 17. Group 15 specifically has ns²np³.

questions.question_text: Nitrogen cannot form NCl₅ while phosphorus can form PCl₅ because:

options.text: Nitrogen does not have vacant d orbitals in its valence shell
Nitrogen forms stronger bonds with chlorine
PCl₅ is more stable than NCl₅ due to the larger size of phosphorus

questions.explanation_correct: Nitrogen belongs to the second period and has only 2s and 2p orbitals available. It lacks vacant d orbitals, limiting its maximum covalency to 4. Phosphorus, being in the third period, has empty 3d orbitals and can expand its octet to form five covalent bonds.
questions.explanation_incorrect: While nitrogen is more electronegative, this is not the reason it cannot form NCl₅. Bond strength is not the limiting factor. The key limitation is the absence of d orbitals in nitrogen's valence shell.

questions.question_text: Ammonia (NH₃) acts as a Lewis base because:

options.text: It has a lone pair of electrons on nitrogen that can be donated

questions.explanation_correct: NH₃ has a lone pair of electrons on the nitrogen atom. A Lewis base is an electron pair donor. NH₃ donates this lone pair to electron-deficient species (Lewis acids) like BF₃ or metal ions, forming coordinate bonds.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Donating a proton would make it a Brønsted acid, not a base. Electronegativity alone does not define Lewis basicity. A Lewis base donates electrons, not accepts them.

questions.question_text: Phosphorous acid (H₃PO₃) is dibasic rather than tribasic because:

options.text: One hydrogen atom is directly bonded to phosphorus (P–H bond) and is not ionisable
It decomposes before the third ionisation
The third hydrogen is bonded to oxygen but is too strongly held

questions.explanation_correct: In H₃PO₃, only two hydrogen atoms are bonded to oxygen through P–OH groups and can ionise. The third hydrogen is directly bonded to phosphorus (P–H bond), which is not ionisable in aqueous solution. Hence, H₃PO₃ is dibasic.
questions.explanation_incorrect: H₃PO₃ does not have three P–OH bonds; it has two P–OH bonds and one P–H bond. It does not need to decompose for ionisation. The third hydrogen is bonded to P, not to O.

questions.question_text: Which of the following nitrogen oxides is a mixed anhydride of HNO₂ and HNO₃?
questions.explanation_correct: N₂O₃ (dinitrogen trioxide) is the mixed anhydride of nitrous acid (HNO₂) and nitric acid (HNO₃). When dissolved in water: N₂O₃ + H₂O → HNO₂ + HNO₃. In N₂O₃, one nitrogen has oxidation state +3 (corresponding to HNO₂) and the other has +3 as well, but structurally it is considered the anhydride of both acids.
questions.explanation_incorrect: N₂O is the anhydride of hyponitrous acid (H₂N₂O₂). N₂O₄ is the dimer of NO₂ and is not a standard anhydride. N₂O₅ is the anhydride of HNO₃ only.

questions.question_text: The bond angle in PH₃ is less than that in NH₃ because:

options.text: Phosphorus has a larger atomic radius, leading to weaker lone pair repulsion
The lone pair on P has less s-character, causing less compression
The P–H bond pairs are less electronegative than N–H bond pairs, so they are repelled less by the lone pair
PH₃ is sp²d hybridised while NH₃ is sp³ hybridised

questions.explanation_correct: In PH₃, the larger size of phosphorus means the bonding pairs are farther from the central atom and from each other, resulting in less bond pair-bond pair repulsion. Additionally, the lone pair on P is more diffuse and exerts less compression on bond angles. The bond angle in PH₃ is ~93.5° compared to ~107° in NH₃.
questions.explanation_incorrect: While s-character arguments exist, the primary explanation at this level is the larger size of P. PH₃ is approximately sp³ hybridised (with more p-character), not sp²d. The electronegativity difference affects polarity but is not the main factor for the angle.

questions.question_text: HNO₃ acts as an oxidising acid when it reacts with copper. The gas evolved and the oxidation state of nitrogen in it are:
questions.explanation_correct: When concentrated HNO₃ reacts with copper: Cu + 4HNO₃(conc.) → Cu(NO₃)₂ + 2NO₂ + 2H₂O. Brown fumes of NO₂ are evolved. In NO₂, the oxidation state of nitrogen is +4 (calculated as x + 2(−2) = 0, so x = +4).
questions.explanation_incorrect: N₂O (oxidation state +1) is formed in some reactions but not with copper and concentrated HNO₃. NO has nitrogen in oxidation state +2 (formed with dilute HNO₃ and copper). N₂ is not a typical product of HNO₃ reactions with metals.

questions.question_text: Which of the following statements about PCl₅ is correct?

options.text: PCl₅ has a square pyramidal structure
All five P–Cl bonds in PCl₅ are equivalent
PCl₅ has a trigonal bipyramidal structure with two types of P–Cl bonds
PCl₅ is more stable than PCl₃ under all conditions

questions.explanation_correct: PCl₅ has a trigonal bipyramidal geometry (sp³d hybridisation). It has two types of P–Cl bonds: three shorter equatorial bonds (204 pm) and two longer axial bonds (219 pm). The axial bonds are longer because they experience greater repulsion from the three equatorial bonds.
questions.explanation_incorrect: PCl₅ is trigonal bipyramidal, not square pyramidal. The five bonds are NOT equivalent — axial and equatorial bonds differ in length. PCl₅ is actually less stable than PCl₃ and readily dissociates: PCl₅ ⇌ PCl₃ + Cl₂.

questions.question_text: The number of P–OH bonds and P=O bonds in pyrophosphoric acid (H₄P₂O₇) are, respectively:
questions.explanation_correct: Pyrophosphoric acid (H₄P₂O₇) has two phosphorus atoms, each bonded to two OH groups and one P=O, with the two PO₄ units linked by a P–O–P bridge. This gives 4 P–OH bonds and 2 P=O bonds in total.
questions.explanation_incorrect: There are two P atoms, each contributing 2 P–OH and 1 P=O. The total is 4 P–OH and 2 P=O. Having only 1 P=O or 0 P=O does not match the structure of pyrophosphoric acid.

questions.question_text: Which allotrope of phosphorus is the most reactive and is stored under water?
questions.explanation_correct: White phosphorus (P₄) is the most reactive allotrope. It is a waxy, translucent solid that ignites spontaneously in air at ~35°C (pyrophoric). Therefore, it is stored under water to prevent contact with air.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Red phosphorus is polymeric and much less reactive; it does not ignite spontaneously. Black phosphorus is the most thermodynamically stable and least reactive allotrope. Violet phosphorus is similar to red phosphorus in stability.

questions.question_text: The basicity of H₃PO₄ (orthophosphoric acid) is:
questions.explanation_correct: H₃PO₄ has three P–OH groups, all of which can ionise to release H⁺ ions. Therefore, it is tribasic. The three ionisations are: H₃PO₄ → H₂PO₄⁻ + H⁺, H₂PO₄⁻ → HPO₄²⁻ + H⁺, HPO₄²⁻ → PO₄³⁻ + H⁺.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Basicity equals the number of ionisable H atoms (those bonded to O via OH groups). H₃PO₄ has 3 OH groups, so its basicity is 3, not 1, 2, or 5.

questions.question_text: In the reaction N₂ + 3H₂ ⇌ 2NH₃, the bond dissociation energy of the N≡N triple bond is very high (~941 kJ/mol). This explains why:

options.text: Nitrogen is relatively inert at room temperature
Nitrogen has a large atomic radius

questions.explanation_correct: The very high bond dissociation energy of the N≡N triple bond (941 kJ/mol) means that breaking the nitrogen molecule requires a large amount of energy. This makes N₂ kinetically inert at room temperature, and the synthesis of NH₃ requires high temperature, pressure, and a catalyst (Haber process).
questions.explanation_incorrect: While the reaction is exothermic, that is due to the overall energy balance, not directly explained by the high bond energy of N₂. NH₃ is a base, not an acid. Nitrogen actually has a small atomic radius (70 pm covalent).

questions.question_text: The general electronic configuration of Group 16 elements is:
questions.explanation_correct: Group 16 elements (O, S, Se, Te, Po) have six electrons in their outermost shell with the configuration ns²np⁴. They need two more electrons to complete their octet and commonly show an oxidation state of −2.
questions.explanation_incorrect: ns²np³ is Group 15, ns²np⁵ is Group 17, and ns²np⁶ is Group 18. Group 16 has ns²np⁴.

questions.question_text: Ozone (O₃) has which of the following structures?

options.text: Angular (bent) with a bond angle of ~117°

questions.explanation_correct: Ozone has an angular (bent) structure with a bond angle of approximately 117°. The central oxygen is sp² hybridised with one lone pair, giving a bent shape. The two O–O bonds are equal in length (~128 pm) due to resonance.
questions.explanation_incorrect: A linear structure would require sp hybridisation without lone pairs. Trigonal planar requires three bonded atoms with no lone pair on the central atom. Tetrahedral requires four bonding groups. Ozone is bent due to the lone pair on the central O.

questions.question_text: In the Contact process for manufacturing H₂SO₄, the catalyst used for the oxidation of SO₂ to SO₃ is:
questions.explanation_correct: In the Contact process, SO₂ is oxidised to SO₃ using V₂O₅ (vanadium pentoxide) as the catalyst at 720 K: 2SO₂ + O₂ → 2SO₃. Previously, platinum was used but V₂O₅ is preferred due to lower cost and resistance to poisoning.
questions.explanation_incorrect: MnO₂ is used in the preparation of Cl₂ from HCl. Fe₂O₃ is used as a catalyst in the Haber process. Platinum was historically used in the Contact process but has been replaced by V₂O₅. The current industrial catalyst is V₂O₅.

questions.question_text: The most stable allotrope of sulphur at room temperature is:
questions.explanation_correct: Rhombic sulphur (α-sulphur) is the most thermodynamically stable allotrope at room temperature. It consists of S₈ molecules arranged in an orthorhombic crystal. Above 369 K, monoclinic sulphur becomes more stable.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Monoclinic sulphur is stable above 369 K, not at room temperature. Plastic sulphur is an amorphous form obtained by quenching molten sulphur. Colloidal sulphur is not a distinct allotrope.

questions.question_text: H₂SO₄ acts as a dehydrating agent when it reacts with sugar (C₁₂H₂₂O₁₁). The product formed is:
questions.explanation_correct: Concentrated H₂SO₄ removes water from sugar: C₁₂H₂₂O₁₁ → 12C + 11H₂O. The sugar chars to form a black spongy mass of carbon, which swells up. This demonstrates the powerful dehydrating nature of concentrated H₂SO₄.
questions.explanation_incorrect: CO₂ is not formed in this dehydration reaction. Hydrolysis to glucose and fructose requires dilute acid and mild conditions. SO₂ is not produced in the dehydration of sugar.

questions.question_text: In the Contact process, SO₃ is not directly absorbed in water because:

options.text: Direct absorption produces a thick mist of H₂SO₄ that is difficult to condense
The reaction is endothermic and requires heating

questions.explanation_correct: When SO₃ is directly dissolved in water, the reaction SO₃ + H₂O → H₂SO₄ is highly exothermic and produces a fine mist of H₂SO₄ droplets that are difficult to condense and collect. Instead, SO₃ is absorbed in concentrated H₂SO₄ to form oleum (H₂S₂O₇), which is then diluted with water.
questions.explanation_incorrect: SO₃ is actually very reactive with water, not insoluble. The reaction is exothermic, not endothermic. SO₃ does not decompose in water. The problem is the formation of an unmanageable acid mist.

questions.question_text: The oxidation state of sulphur in H₂SO₄ is:
questions.explanation_correct: In H₂SO₄: 2(+1) + x + 4(−2) = 0, so x = +6. Sulphur has an oxidation state of +6, which is the maximum oxidation state for sulphur (using all six valence electrons for bonding).
questions.explanation_incorrect: +2 is the oxidation state of S in some compounds like SCl₂. +4 is found in SO₂ and H₂SO₃. −2 is found in H₂S. In H₂SO₄, sulphur is in its highest oxidation state of +6.

questions.question_text: Which of the following correctly describes why H₂O is a liquid at room temperature while H₂S is a gas?

options.text: H₂O has a higher molecular weight than H₂S
H₂O forms strong intermolecular hydrogen bonds due to high electronegativity and small size of oxygen
H₂S is less polar than H₂O
H₂S has weaker covalent bonds than H₂O

questions.explanation_correct: H₂O is a liquid at room temperature because oxygen is small and highly electronegative, enabling strong O–H···O hydrogen bonds between water molecules. H₂S cannot form significant hydrogen bonds because sulphur is larger, less electronegative, and the S–H bond is less polar. H₂S has only weak van der Waals forces.
questions.explanation_incorrect: H₂O (18 g/mol) is actually lighter than H₂S (34 g/mol), so molecular weight does not explain this. While H₂S is indeed less polar, the key reason is hydrogen bonding. Bond strength (covalent) affects chemical reactivity, not boiling point directly.

questions.question_text: SO₂ acts as a reducing agent when it reacts with acidified KMnO₄ solution. Which observation confirms this?

options.text: The purple/pink colour of KMnO₄ is decolourised
Effervescence of a colourless gas occurs

questions.explanation_correct: SO₂ reduces the purple MnO₄⁻ (Mn in +7 state) to colourless Mn²⁺ (Mn in +2 state) in acidic medium: 5SO₂ + 2KMnO₄ + 2H₂O → K₂SO₄ + 2MnSO₄ + 2H₂SO₄. The decolourisation of KMnO₄ confirms SO₂'s reducing nature.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The solution does not turn blue. No yellow precipitate forms in this reaction. There is no effervescence. The key observation is the loss of the characteristic purple/pink colour of permanganate.

questions.question_text:
Assertion (A): Sulphur in the vapour state shows paramagnetic behaviour.
Reason (R): In the vapour state at high temperature, S₂ molecules are formed which have two unpaired electrons like O₂.
Choose the correct option:

options.text: Both A and R are true, and R is the correct explanation of A
Both A and R are true, but R is not the correct explanation of A
A is true but R is false
A is false but R is true

questions.explanation_correct: Both assertion and reason are true, and R correctly explains A. At very high temperatures (~1000°C), sulphur vapour consists of S₂ molecules. Like O₂, S₂ has two unpaired electrons in its antibonding π* orbitals (according to MOT), making it paramagnetic.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Both the assertion and the reason are factually correct. S₂ is isoelectronic in valence terms with O₂ and has the same paramagnetic behaviour. The reason directly explains the paramagnetic nature stated in the assertion.

questions.question_text: The element with the highest electron affinity is:
questions.explanation_correct: Chlorine has the highest electron affinity (−349 kJ/mol) among all elements. Although fluorine is the most electronegative, its small size causes strong electron-electron repulsion in the compact 2p subshell, resulting in a lower electron affinity (−328 kJ/mol) than chlorine.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Fluorine, despite being the most electronegative, has a lower electron affinity than chlorine due to its very small size and high electron density. Bromine and iodine have progressively lower electron affinities due to increasing size.

questions.question_text: Among the hydrogen halides (HF, HCl, HBr, HI), which has the highest boiling point?
questions.explanation_correct: HF has the highest boiling point (19.5°C) among hydrogen halides because fluorine is small and highly electronegative, enabling strong intermolecular hydrogen bonding (F–H···F). The other hydrogen halides do not form significant hydrogen bonds.
questions.explanation_incorrect: HI, HBr, and HCl boil at −35°C, −67°C, and −85°C respectively, all well below HF. Despite HI having the highest molecular weight (and therefore strongest van der Waals forces among HCl, HBr, HI), hydrogen bonding in HF dominates.

questions.question_text: Fluorine is the strongest oxidising agent among the halogens. Which of the following is NOT a reason for this?

options.text: High hydration enthalpy of F⁻ ion

questions.explanation_correct: The high ionisation energy of fluorine is irrelevant to its oxidising power. An oxidising agent gains electrons, not loses them. The factors making F₂ the strongest oxidising halogen are: low F–F bond dissociation energy (158 kJ/mol), high electronegativity, and very high hydration enthalpy of the small F⁻ ion.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Low bond dissociation energy, high hydration enthalpy of F⁻, and high electron affinity all contribute to fluorine's strong oxidising power. Ionisation energy relates to losing electrons (which is not what an oxidising agent does).

questions.question_text: The correct order of acid strength among the oxoacids of chlorine is:
questions.explanation_correct: Acid strength increases with the number of oxygen atoms bonded to the central atom. More oxygen atoms withdraw electron density from the O–H bond, making it easier to release H⁺. Also, the conjugate base is stabilised by delocalisation over more oxygen atoms. Order: HClO₄ (strongest) > HClO₃ > HClO₂ > HClO (weakest).
questions.explanation_incorrect: The reverse order would represent increasing oxidising power, not acid strength. The number of oxygen atoms increases the inductive pull on the O–H bond, increasing acid strength in the order shown.

questions.question_text: Interhalogen compound ClF₃ has a shape that is best described as:
questions.explanation_correct: ClF₃ has 5 electron pairs around Cl (3 bonding + 2 lone pairs), giving sp³d hybridisation. The two lone pairs occupy equatorial positions (to minimise repulsion), resulting in a T-shaped geometry with the three F atoms in a T arrangement.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Trigonal planar would require 3 bonding pairs and no lone pairs. Pyramidal would require 3 bonding pairs and 1 lone pair. Linear would require 2 bonding pairs. The two lone pairs in ClF₃ create a T-shaped structure.

questions.question_text: The correct order of bond dissociation energy of halogens (X₂) is:
questions.explanation_correct: The bond dissociation energies are: Cl₂ (242 kJ/mol) > F₂ (158 kJ/mol) > Br₂ (193 kJ/mol) > I₂ (151 kJ/mol). Wait — the actual values are Cl₂ (242) > Br₂ (193) > F₂ (158) > I₂ (151). However, the commonly cited CBSE order is Cl₂ > Br₂ > F₂ > I₂. F₂ has an anomalously low bond dissociation energy due to strong lone pair-lone pair repulsion between the small fluorine atoms.
questions.explanation_incorrect: F₂ does NOT have the highest bond dissociation energy despite being the smallest halogen. The small size of F atoms causes severe lone pair repulsions, weakening the F–F bond. The order Cl₂ > Br₂ > F₂ > I₂ accounts for this anomaly.

questions.question_text: Which interhalogen compound has a pentagonal bipyramidal structure?
questions.explanation_correct: IF₇ has 7 fluorine atoms bonded to iodine with no lone pairs. It adopts a pentagonal bipyramidal geometry (sp³d³ hybridisation), which is the only interhalogen compound of the type XY₇. It has 5 F atoms in the pentagonal plane and 2 F atoms in axial positions.
questions.explanation_incorrect: ClF₃ is T-shaped (sp³d with 2 lone pairs). BrF₅ is square pyramidal (sp³d² with 1 lone pair). ICl₃ exists as a dimer I₂Cl₆ with a planar structure. Only IF₇ has the pentagonal bipyramidal shape.

questions.question_text: Fluorine exhibits only −1 oxidation state in its compounds, while other halogens exhibit positive oxidation states because:

options.text: Fluorine has the largest atomic radius
Fluorine does not have d orbitals in its valence shell and is the most electronegative element
Fluorine has the weakest bond dissociation energy

questions.explanation_correct: Fluorine, being in the second period, has no available d orbitals to expand its octet. Additionally, it is the most electronegative element, so it always attracts the shared pair towards itself. Other halogens (Cl, Br, I) have vacant d orbitals and can show +1, +3, +5, +7 states when bonded to more electronegative atoms (like O and F).
questions.explanation_incorrect: Fluorine has the smallest atomic radius, not the largest. While F₂ does have a low bond dissociation energy, this is not the reason for its fixed −1 state. Fluorine forms both ionic and covalent compounds.

questions.question_text: When chlorine water is added to an aqueous solution of KBr, the solution turns brown. This is because:

options.text: KCl is formed which is brown in colour
Cl₂ oxidises Br⁻ to Br₂, which gives the brown colour
HCl is formed which is brown
Chlorine dissolves in KBr to form a brown complex

questions.explanation_correct: Chlorine, being a stronger oxidising agent than bromine, displaces bromine from KBr: Cl₂ + 2KBr → 2KCl + Br₂. The liberated bromine (Br₂) gives the solution its characteristic brown/reddish-brown colour.
questions.explanation_incorrect: KCl is colourless. HCl is colourless. No complex is formed. The brown colour is specifically due to free Br₂ produced by oxidation of Br⁻ by Cl₂.

questions.question_text: The oxidation state of chlorine in bleaching powder (CaOCl₂) is:
questions.explanation_correct: Bleaching powder is calcium hypochlorite with chloride: Ca(OCl)Cl. It contains two types of chlorine atoms — one in OCl⁻ (hypochlorite, Cl in +1 state) and one as Cl⁻ (chloride, Cl in −1 state).
questions.explanation_incorrect: Bleaching powder contains chlorine in two different oxidation states. It has both +1 (in the hypochlorite part OCl⁻) and −1 (in the chloride part Cl⁻). Neither 0 nor any single state accounts for both.

questions.question_text: Among the halogen acids, the reducing power follows the order:
questions.explanation_correct: Reducing power of halogen acids increases from HF to HI: HI > HBr > HCl > HF. This is because the H–X bond strength decreases from HF to HI (H–F: 568, H–Cl: 431, H–Br: 366, H–I: 297 kJ/mol), making HI the easiest to break and the strongest reducing agent.
questions.explanation_incorrect: HF is the weakest reducing agent due to its very strong H–F bond. The order is the reverse of bond strength order. HI, with the weakest H–I bond, is the strongest reducing agent among the halogen acids.

questions.question_text: Noble gases have very low boiling points because:

options.text: They have completely filled orbitals and experience only weak van der Waals forces
They have very high ionisation energies
They are lighter than other gases

questions.explanation_correct: Noble gases are monoatomic with completely filled electronic configurations. They do not form bonds with each other and experience only weak van der Waals (London dispersion) forces. These weak intermolecular forces result in very low boiling points.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Noble gases do not form covalent bonds with each other. High ionisation energy explains their chemical inertness, not their boiling points. Not all noble gases are light (Rn has a high atomic mass). The key factor is the weakness of their intermolecular forces.

questions.question_text: The first noble gas compound to be prepared was:
questions.explanation_correct: Neil Bartlett in 1962 prepared the first noble gas compound, Xe[PtF₆] (xenon hexafluoroplatinate), by reacting xenon with PtF₆. He reasoned that since the ionisation energy of Xe (~1170 kJ/mol) is comparable to that of O₂ (~1175 kJ/mol), and O₂ forms O₂⁺[PtF₆]⁻, xenon should also react with PtF₆.
questions.explanation_incorrect: XeF₂, XeF₄, and XeO₃ were prepared after Bartlett's discovery. The first compound was Xe[PtF₆], prepared based on the analogy between the ionisation energies of Xe and O₂.

questions.question_text: The shape of XeF₂ is:
questions.explanation_correct: XeF₂ has 5 electron pairs around Xe (2 bonding + 3 lone pairs), giving sp³d hybridisation. The three lone pairs occupy the equatorial positions in a trigonal bipyramidal arrangement, leaving the two F atoms in axial positions, resulting in a linear shape with a bond angle of 180°.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Bent shape would require 2 bonding pairs and 1 or 2 lone pairs in a different arrangement. Trigonal planar requires 3 bonding pairs and no lone pairs. Tetrahedral requires 4 bonding pairs. The 3 lone pairs on Xe force the linear geometry.

questions.question_text: XeF₄ has a square planar structure. The hybridisation of xenon in XeF₄ is:
questions.explanation_correct: XeF₄ has 6 electron pairs around Xe (4 bonding + 2 lone pairs), requiring sp³d² hybridisation. The 2 lone pairs are placed opposite each other (trans positions) in the octahedral arrangement to minimise lone pair-lone pair repulsion, resulting in a square planar geometry.
questions.explanation_incorrect: sp³ involves only 4 electron pairs. sp³d involves 5 electron pairs. sp³d³ involves 7 electron pairs. XeF₄ with 6 electron pairs requires sp³d² hybridisation.

questions.question_text: Xenon does not form compounds with all noble gas elements because:

options.text: Xenon is the most reactive noble gas
Lighter noble gases (He, Ne, Ar) have very high ionisation energies and no available d orbitals (for He, Ne) to expand their octet
Xenon has the lowest electronegativity among noble gases
Only xenon can form ionic bonds

questions.explanation_correct: He and Ne have no d orbitals in their valence shell and cannot expand their octet. Ar has 3d orbitals but its ionisation energy is too high (~1521 kJ/mol) for practical compound formation. Xenon has the lowest ionisation energy (~1170 kJ/mol) among stable noble gases and has 5d orbitals, making it the most amenable to compound formation.
questions.explanation_incorrect: While Xe is the most reactive noble gas, the question asks why other noble gases do not form compounds. Xe's electronegativity is not the determining factor. Noble gas compounds are primarily covalent, not ionic.

questions.question_text: The reaction of XeF₂ with water gives:
questions.explanation_correct: XeF₂ undergoes hydrolysis with water: 2XeF₂ + 2H₂O → 2Xe + 4HF + O₂. The xenon is reduced to its elemental form (Xe), and oxygen is liberated. This is because XeF₂ is a strong fluorinating and oxidising agent.
questions.explanation_incorrect: XeO₃ is formed by hydrolysis of XeF₆, not XeF₂. XeOF₂ is an intermediate in XeF₄ hydrolysis. XeF₄ is not formed from XeF₂ and water. The complete hydrolysis of XeF₂ gives Xe, HF, and O₂.

questions.question_text: The shape of XeOF₂ is:
questions.explanation_correct: XeOF₂ has 5 electron pairs around Xe (1 Xe=O + 2 Xe–F bonds + 2 lone pairs = 5 electron domains). With sp³d hybridisation, the 2 lone pairs occupy equatorial positions, and the O and 2 F atoms form a T-shaped arrangement.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Trigonal planar would require 3 bonding groups and no lone pairs. Pyramidal requires 3 bonding groups and 1 lone pair. See-saw requires 4 bonding groups and 1 lone pair. The 2 lone pairs in XeOF₂ dictate the T-shape.

questions.question_text: XeF₆ on complete hydrolysis gives:
questions.explanation_correct: XeF₆ undergoes complete hydrolysis with excess water: XeF₆ + 3H₂O → XeO₃ + 6HF. XeO₃ is a colourless, explosive solid. Partial hydrolysis gives XeOF₄ and XeO₂F₂ as intermediates.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Xe and HF would be the products if XeF₂ were hydrolysed. XeOF₄ is formed only by partial hydrolysis of XeF₆. XeO₂ is not a standard product. Complete hydrolysis gives XeO₃ and 6HF.

questions.question_text: The shape of SF₆ is:
questions.explanation_correct: SF₆ has 6 bonding pairs and no lone pairs around sulphur, with sp³d² hybridisation. This gives a regular octahedral geometry with all F–S–F bond angles equal to 90°.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Trigonal bipyramidal has 5 electron pairs. Square planar results from 6 electron pairs with 2 lone pairs. Pentagonal bipyramidal has 7 electron pairs. SF₆ with 6 bonding pairs and no lone pairs is a perfect octahedron.

questions.question_text: The shape of BrF₅ is:
questions.explanation_correct: BrF₅ has 6 electron pairs around Br (5 bonding + 1 lone pair), with sp³d² hybridisation. The lone pair occupies one position of the octahedral arrangement, giving a square pyramidal shape.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Trigonal bipyramidal has 5 electron pairs with no lone pairs. Pentagonal planar is not a standard VSEPR geometry. Octahedral requires 6 bonding pairs with no lone pairs. The single lone pair in BrF₅ gives it a square pyramidal shape.

questions.question_text: Which of the following oxoacids of phosphorus has the highest basicity?
questions.explanation_correct: Basicity is determined by the number of P–OH groups. H₃PO₄ has 3 P–OH groups (basicity = 3). H₃PO₃ has 2 P–OH groups (basicity = 2). H₃PO₂ has 1 P–OH group (basicity = 1). HPO₃ has 1 P–OH group (basicity = 1). So H₃PO₄ has the highest basicity.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Despite H₃PO₂ having three hydrogen atoms in its formula, only one is in a P–OH group (the other two are P–H). H₃PO₃ has 2 P–OH groups. HPO₃ has 1 P–OH. H₃PO₄ with 3 P–OH groups has the highest basicity.

questions.question_text: Concentrated H₂SO₄ cannot be used to prepare HBr from NaBr because:

options.text: NaBr does not react with H₂SO₄
H₂SO₄ is a weaker acid than HBr

questions.explanation_correct: Concentrated H₂SO₄ is a strong oxidising agent. While it does initially form HBr from NaBr (NaBr + H₂SO₄ → NaHSO₄ + HBr), the H₂SO₄ then oxidises the HBr to Br₂: 2HBr + H₂SO₄ → Br₂ + SO₂ + 2H₂O. For the same reason, HI cannot be prepared using H₂SO₄. Instead, NaBr is treated with H₃PO₄ (a non-oxidising acid).
questions.explanation_incorrect: NaBr does react with H₂SO₄. NaBr is stable at room temperature. H₂SO₄ is a strong acid. The issue is the oxidising nature of concentrated H₂SO₄, which converts HBr to Br₂.

questions.question_text: The electronic configuration of xenon (Z = 54) is:
questions.explanation_correct: Xenon (Z = 54) is a noble gas in Group 18 with a completely filled electronic configuration: [Kr] 4d¹⁰ 5s² 5p⁶. The fully filled valence shell (5s² 5p⁶) gives it chemical stability and a very high ionisation energy.
questions.explanation_incorrect: [Kr] 4d¹⁰ 5s² 5p⁵ is for iodine (Z = 53). 5p⁴ corresponds to tellurium (Z = 52). 5p³ corresponds to antimony (Z = 51). Xenon has the complete 5p⁶ configuration.

questions.question_text: The structure of H₂S₂O₇ (oleum or pyrosulphuric acid) contains:
questions.explanation_correct: Oleum (H₂S₂O₇ or pyrosulphuric acid) has two SO₃(OH) units connected by an S–O–S bridge. Each sulphur has 2 S=O double bonds, 1 S–OH, and shares one oxygen with the other sulphur through the bridging O atom.
questions.explanation_incorrect: There is no direct S–S bond in H₂S₂O₇. A peroxide linkage (O–O) is found in H₂S₂O₈ (peroxodisulphuric acid), not oleum. The two SO₃ groups are connected, not isolated.

questions.question_text: N₂O₅ is the anhydride of which acid?
questions.explanation_correct: N₂O₅ is the anhydride of nitric acid (HNO₃). When dissolved in water: N₂O₅ + H₂O → 2HNO₃. In N₂O₅, nitrogen has an oxidation state of +5, which matches the +5 oxidation state in HNO₃.
questions.explanation_incorrect: HNO₂ (N in +3 state) has N₂O₃ as its anhydride. H₂N₂O₂ has N₂O as its anhydride. HNO is not a standard acid. N₂O₅ corresponds specifically to HNO₃.

questions.question_text: The oxidising power of oxoacids of chlorine follows the order:
questions.explanation_correct: The oxidising power of oxoacids of chlorine decreases with increasing number of oxygen atoms: HClO > HClO₂ > HClO₃ > HClO₄. This is opposite to the trend in acid strength. HClO is the strongest oxidising agent because chlorine in +1 state can easily gain electrons to go to −1.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The oxidising power trend is the reverse of the acid strength trend. HClO₄ is the strongest acid but the weakest oxidising agent. HClO, with Cl in +1 state, is the most powerful oxidiser.

questions.question_text: Which of the following statements about XeO₃ is correct?

options.text: XeO₃ is pyramidal with sp³ hybridisation of Xe and one lone pair
XeO₃ is trigonal planar with sp² hybridisation
XeO₃ is T-shaped with sp³d hybridisation
XeO₃ is linear with sp hybridisation

questions.explanation_correct: XeO₃ has 4 electron pairs around Xe (3 Xe=O bonds + 1 lone pair), giving sp³ hybridisation. The lone pair occupies one corner of the tetrahedron, making the molecular geometry pyramidal (trigonal pyramidal). XeO₃ is explosive and acts as a powerful oxidising agent.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Trigonal planar would require 3 bonding groups and no lone pairs. T-shaped requires 3 bonding groups and 2 lone pairs. Linear requires 2 bonding groups. XeO₃ with one lone pair has a pyramidal shape.
